questions.question: Which of the following options is false in a patient with advanced liver disease?

options.D: Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamine from alpha-ketoglutarate

questions.explanation: reaction is involved in the catabolism of amino acids. It is responsible for the generation and transport of ammonia from peripheral cells to the liver. The conversion of glutamate to alpha-ketoglutarate occurs only in the liver (oxidative decarboxylation). Hence, in the case of advanced liver disease, this will not be possible. Transamination Process Transfer of an α -amino group from an amino acid to one keto acid, producing a new α -keto acid and a new amino acid. The first step is the catabolism of most amino acids. All amino acids, except Proline, hydroxyproline, threonine, and lysine, participate in transamination . Biological Importance Amino Acid Interconversion: Maintains balance of non-essential amino acids by transferring amino groups to synthesise needed amino acids. Ammonia Disposal: Detoxifies ammonia by funnelling amino groups into glutamate, which is deaminated in the liver for excretion. Glutamate's Role α -Ketoglutarate: Acts as an acceptor of amino groups from most amino acids, converting to glutamate. Transamination occurs in the cytoplasm; the amino group is transported to the liver as glutamate. Oxidative Deamination: Glutamate undergoes rapid oxidative deamination in the mitochondria to form α -ketoglutarate, which can accept another amino group. Enzymes Aminotransferases (Transaminases): Catalyse the transfer of amino groups between carbon skeletons. They are not coenzymes. Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT): Transfers amino group from alanine to α -ketoglutarate, forming pyruvate and glutamate. Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST): Transfers amino groups from glutamate to oxaloacetate, forming aspartate used in the urea cycle. Coenzyme Pyridoxal Phosphate (PLP): Required by all aminotransferases, derived from vitamin B6. Reversibility Transamination reactions are reversible, with equilibrium constants near 1. Hyperammonemia (Option A) occur due to Depletion of alpha-ketoglutarate = TCA cycle is affected and ATP is not produced. Decreased ATP synthesis (OptionB) As alpha-ketoglutarate is depleted, the Krebs cycle is affected and the amount of ATP produced decreases. Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate from alpha-ketoglutarate (Option D) due to liver failure, the transamination reaction will not be able to occur Reference: Harper’s biochemistry 32nd edition, Pg 282,283,291 Vasudevan 7th edition, Pg 201

questions.question: All of the following are lipotropic factors except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Arginine Explanation: Arginine is an amino acid involved in nitric oxide production and other functions but is not considered a lipotropic factor. Lipotropic factors Lipotropic factors are nutrients such as choline, betaine, and methionine that help improve liver function and detoxification. (Option A & D ruled out) Lecithin contains choline as its primary active ingredient and is considered a lipotropic agent. (Option B ruled out) These compounds promote the flow of fat and bile to and from the liver, aiding fat metabolism and liver health. They are used to treat liver disorders like hepatitis, cirrhosis, and chemical-induced liver disease. Lipotropic formulas may increase the liver's levels of S-adenosyl-methionine and glutathione, key compounds for liver function and detoxification. Common lipotropic agents include choline, methionine, betaine, folic acid, and vitamin B12. These formulas support detoxification, protect liver function, and enhance fat metabolism. They may also play a role in methylation and epigenetics, influencing health at a molecular level. Carnitine , another lipotropic agent, helps prevent alcohol-induced fatty liver disease by improving fatty acid metabolism. Lipotropic formulas are also used in detoxification, especially in conditions like chronic candidiasis and liver damage. Daily recommended doses for choline and methionine are 1000 mg each . Lipotropic agents are often combined with other herbs and nutrients to support liver health and detoxification. Reference: Lipotropic Agent - an overview | ScienceDirect Topics Lipotropic factors and oncogenesis - PubMed https://www.healthline.com/health/lipotropic-injections

questions.question: A patient came to the hospital with a complaint of abdominal pain. Routine investigations were unremarkable. On observation, the urine turned black on standing. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be defective in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Homogentisate oxidase Explanation: The clinical presentation of black urine on standing along with abdominal pain points to alkaptonuria , a rare autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate oxidase. Homogentisate oxidase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of the amino acids tyrosine and phenylalanine. Its deficiency leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in the body. Pathophysiology: Homogentisic acid is excreted in the urine. Upon exposure to air (oxidation), it polymerizes, causing the urine to turn black on standing. Clinical Features Urine discoloration: The hallmark sign is black urine when exposed to air. Abdominal pain: Likely due to deposition of homogentisic acid or associated complications like kidney stones. Ochronosis : Long-term deposition of homogentisic acid in connective tissues, leading to bluish-black discoloration (typically seen in adulthood). Arthropathy : Degenerative joint disease due to ochronotic deposits in cartilage. Diagnosis: Urine analysis: Elevated levels of homogentisic acid. Genetic testing: Mutations in the HGD gene (homogentisate oxidase gene). Management: Limit intake of tyrosine and phenylalanine. Vitamin C may slow ochronosis progression. Nitisinone : A newer drug that inhibits the production of homogentisic acid by blocking the enzyme upstream in the metabolic pathway. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3978898/

questions.question: In a patient with obstructive jaundice, which of the following outcomes may be observed in Van der Bergh's reaction?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Direct Positive Explanation: Van der Bergh's reaction measures bilirubin levels in blood using diazotized sulfanilic acid. It differentiates between unconjugated (indirect) and conjugated (direct) bilirubin. Elevated direct bilirubin suggests excretion issue like obstructive jaundice. Elevated indirect bilirubin may indicate increased production or liver impairment. Obstructive jaundice: Blocks bile flow, causing accumulation of direct bilirubin. Van der Bergh's reaction in obstructive jaundice: Direct positive result due to increased conjugated bilirubin. Reference: Obstructive jaundice

questions.question: Nitric oxide is synthesized from:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) L-Arginine Explanation: Nitric oxide (NO) is synthesized from the amino acid L-arginine by a group of enzymes called nitric oxide synthases (NOS). The process involves the conversion of L-arginine to NO and L-citrulline. L-arginine: It is the primary precursor for the synthesis of nitric oxide in the body. Nitric oxide synthases convert L-arginine to nitric oxide and L-citrulline in a reaction that requires oxygen and cofactors. The synthesis of nitric oxide (NO) from L-arginine involves a reaction catalyzed by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS). The general equation for NO synthesis is as follows: L-arginine + NADPH + O 2 + H* → Nitric oxide + L-citrulline + NADP+ + H 2 O There are three isoforms of NOS: Endothelial NOS (eNOS) Neuronal NOS (NOS) Inducible NOS (iNOS). Reference: NO

questions.question: The maximum thermic effect is seen with a meal that has

options.D: Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount

questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Protein Thermic effect of food (TEF) refers to the increase in energy expenditure due to digestion, absorption, and metabolism of nutrients. Protein: Has the highest thermic effect (~20–30% of its energy content), as it requires significant energy for metabolism and nitrogen disposal. Fat: Has the lowest thermic effect (~0–3%), as it is metabolized more efficiently with minimal energy expenditure. Carbohydrates: Moderate thermic effect (~5–10%) , primarily for digestion and conversion into glycogen or fat. Mixed meal: The thermic effect of a mixed meal depends on its macronutrient composition but will generally be lower than a protein-rich meal if all components are equal. Reference: TEF

questions.question: The given chemical structure is of:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Chondroitin sulfate Explanation: Chondroitin sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) that is a major component of the extracellular matrix and connective tissues in the body. It consists of repeating units of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) and glucuronic acid (GIcA) or iduronic acid (Ido). Chondroitin sulfate provides structural support and elasticity to various tissues, including cartilage, tendons, ligaments, and skin. Keratan sulfate(Options A): Another type of glycosaminoglycan. It consists of repeating units of galactose and N-acetylglucosamine. It is commonly found in the cornea of the eye and cartilage, and it helps maintain the structural integrity of these tissues. Heparin(Options C): Different type of glycosaminoglycan that is highly sulfated. It consists of repeating units of glucuronic acid and N-acetylglucosamine. Heparin is an anticoagulant and is primarily produced and stored in mast cells. It plays a role in preventing blood clotting. Dermatan sulfate(Options D): Another glycosaminoglycan that is composed of repeating units of iduronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine. It is found in various tissues, including skin, blood vessels, and heart valves. Reference: Chondritin sulfate

questions.question: Which of the following is not a true statement regarding telomerase?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Involved in DNA repair Explanation: Telomerase is not involved in DNA repair process. Telomerase: An RNA-dependent DNA polymerase that counteracts telomere shortening. It is the enzyme responsible for telomere synthesis . Adds TTAGGG repeats to the 3 ′ ends of chromosomes. Contains its own RNA template, which is complementary to the telomeric DNA sequence, enabling it to extend telomeres. Has reverse transcriptase activity (Option A): Telomerase extends the telomeres using its reverse transcriptase activity. Present only in Eukaryotes (Option B): Telomerase is found in eukaryotes, as prokaryotes have circular DNA and do not require telomerase. Maintain the chromosome length (Option C): Telomerase prevents the shortening of chromosomes during replication. Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Pg. 365 Vasudevan, 7th Ed. Pg 585 Telomeres and telomere length

questions.question: Ammonia in the brain is detoxified to form
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Glutamine Explanation: Ammonia in Brian is detoxified to form Glutamine. Glutamine synthetase in astrocytes converts glutamate and ammonia to glutamine, effectively detoxifying ammonia in the brain. Ammonia Management in Neurons: Ammonia can be neurotoxic if accumulated. Glutamine Synthesis: Produced in neurons as a byproduct of amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter turnover. Ammonia reacts with α -ketoglutarate and NADH to form glutamate, catalyzed by glutamate dehydrogenase. α -ketoglutarate + NH 3 I I + NADH → Glutamate + NAD + + H2 I O Glutamate is converted to glutamine by glutamine synthetase, adding another ammonia molecule. Glutamine synthetase is predominantly found in astrocytes. Glutamate + NH 3 I + ATP → Glutamine + ADP + Pi This conversion reduces ammonia toxicity by storing it in a non-toxic form. The fate of glutamine: Release into the Bloodstream: Glutamine is released into the extracellular space and enters the bloodstream. This transport helps maintain nitrogen balance and prevents ammonia accumulation. Transport to the Liver: Glutamine carries ammonia from the brain to the liver, where it is deaminated to release ammonia. Ammonia enters the urea cycle in the liver for detoxification. Importance of Glutamine in Neuronal Health: Acts as a non-toxic ammonia carrier, preventing neurotoxicity. Serves as a precursor for neurotransmitters like GABA , maintaining neurotransmitter balance. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8244593/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4133642/ https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S019701862030200X

questions.question: A young girl presented to the OPD for an examination. She is tall and thin with slender fingers, and dislocated lenses. Workup revealed cystathione beta-synthase deficiency. Which amino acid supplement is required in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Cysteine Explanation: The Clinical scenario of tall, thin and dislocated lens with cystathione beta synthase deficiency indicates Type 1 Homocystinuria. Cysteine is deficient in this patient, thus supplement is required in this case. Type 1 vs Type 2 Homocystinuria: Feature Type - I Homocystinuria Type - II Homocystinuria Enzyme Deficiency Cystathionine beta-synthase Methionine synthase Metabolic Pathway Affected Homocysteine to cystathionine Homocysteine to methionine Elevated Metabolites Homocysteine and methionine Homocysteine and elevated levels of Cysteine Biochemical Diagnosis Low levels of cysteine. High levels of methionine. High levels of cysteine. Low levels of methionine. Treatment Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation; low-methionine diet; cysteine supplementation Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation; low-methionine diet Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry . 32nd edition p.294, 295 Vasudevan Textbook of Biochemistry (7th Edition), Page 431.

questions.question: A patient presented with joint pain and on evaluation, urine turns black on standing. What is the likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.explanation: including darkening of urine upon standing and joint pain, is characteristic of Alkaptonuria , which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate oxidase. Garrod's tetrad in alkaptonuria 1. Homogentisic Aciduria Presence of homogentisic acid in the urine, which turns dark upon standing or when exposed to air. 2. Ochronosis Deposition of dark pigment in connective tissues, particularly noticeable in the ear cartilage, sclera, and other connective tissues, leading to a bluish-black discoloration.The image shows Osler’s sign. 3. Arthropathy Degenerative joint disease, especially affecting the spine and large joints, leading to chronic pain and stiffness. 4. Cardiac Involvement Includes heart valve calcification and atherosclerosis due to the deposition of pigment in cardiac tissues. Reaction Enzyme Associated Disorder Tyrosine → p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate Tyrosine transaminase Tyrosinemia type II p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate → Homogentisate p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase Tyrosinemia type III Homogentisate → Maleylacetoacetate Homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase Alkaptonuria Maleylacetoacetate → Fumarylacetoacetate Maleylacetoacetate isomerase - Fumarylacetoacetate → Fumarate + Acetoacetate Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase Tyrosinemia type I

questions.question: Which of the following does not contribute to the repair of DNA double-stranded breaks?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) ATP Explanation: ATP is not directly involved in the repair of DNA double-stranded breaks (DSBs), but it provides the energy necessary for many cellular processes, including DNA repair. Homologous DNA Repair (HR) HR is a type of Double-strand DNA break repair mechanism used to fix double-strand breaks (DSBs) by utilizing a homologous DNA template for error-free repair. HR is active during the S and G2 phases of the cell cycle. RAD 51 and ATM are involved in the G2 phase Nonhomologous End Joining (NHEJ) NHEJ is a DNA repair mechanism that fixes double-strand breaks (DSBs) by directly joining the broken ends without requiring a homologous template. Active throughout the entire cell cycle, including G0/G1 phases. Ku70 is involved in the G1 phase Reference: Harper 32nd edition, pg 380 Lippincott 7th edition, 1219-1222 Holliday junction

questions.question: Which of the following consumes the highest energy during assimilation?
questions.explanation: and require maximum energy. Carbohydrates (Option B) utilizes less energy for assimilation 5%. MUFA (Option C) has a single double bond and consumes the least energy to be broken down. PUFA (Option D) are essential amino acids required by our body and require the least energy to be broken down. Reference: Vasudevan Textbook of Biochemistry, 7th Edition, Page 529

questions.question: Which enzyme is likely to be deficient in a 4-year-old child who presents with a habit of biting their lips and fingers, and has a missing portion of fingers on their left hand? Further evaluation shows delayed developmental milestones. The parents report that two male cousins on the mother's side have similar symptoms and have been diagnosed with a genetic disorder. Laboratory reports indicate hyperuricemia.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hypoxanthine -guanine phosphoribosyl transferase. Explanation: Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome (X-linked recessive disorder) Enzyme deficiency: HGPRT deficiency impairs the purine salvage pathway. Excess uric acid production (hyperuricemia) due to increased purine breakdown. Neurological symptoms due to the lack of purine recycling, affecting brain development. Key symptoms: Self-mutilation behavior (lip and finger biting) IIII II II II II II I I I I II II II II Developmental delay Hyperuricemia → Gout, nephrolithiasis X-linked inheritance: Symptoms in males, family history consistent with maternal transmission. Purine nucleoside phosphorylase (Option A): Inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Adenine phosphoribosyl transferase (Option C): Deficiency is characterised by excessive production and renal excretion of 2,8-dihydroxyadenine (DHA), which leads to kidney stone formation and crystal-induced kidney damage (DHA crystal nephropathy). Adenosine deaminase (Option D): Deficiency damages the immune system and causes severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a universal methyl group donor in various biochemical reactions?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) S-Adenosyl Methionine Explanation: S-Adenosyl Methionine (SAM) is the universal methyl group donor in various biochemical reactions. Key Features of SAM: Formed from methionine and ATP. Transfers methyl groups (-CH I ) to a variety of molecules, including: DNA (methylation) Neurotransmitters (e.g., epinephrine synthesis) Phospholipids After donating its methyl group, it becomes S-adenosyl homocysteine (SAH), which can be recycled back to methionine via the methionine cycle. Glucose-6-phosphate (Option A): Involved in glycolysis and the HMP shunt, not methylation. Acetyl CoA (Option B): Donates acetyl groups (not methyl) in pathways like the TCA cycle and fatty acid synthesis. S-Adenosyl Serine (Option D): No significant role as a methyl donor. Reference: Methyl donor

questions.question: What is the enzyme that is responsible for the defect causing Maple syrup urine disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Branched-chain a-ketoacid dehydrogenase Explanation: Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD): Autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme branched-chain α -ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKD) , Responsible for the breakdown of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs): Leucine Isoleucine Valine Enzyme Function and Pathophysiology: BCKD is a mitochondrial multienzyme complex that catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of branched-chain α -keto acids. These α -keto acids are derived from the transamination of BCAAs. Deficiency Results In: Accumulation of BCAAs and their α -keto acid derivatives (e.g., α -ketoisocaproic acid). Toxic metabolites lead to severe neurological dysfunction due to their impact on brain metabolism. Clinical Features: Neonatal onset : Usually presents within the first few days of life. Poor feeding Vomiting Lethargy Maple syrup odor of urine (due to isoleucine metabolite sotolone) Seizures Neurological damage: Due to leucine accumulation affecting brain function. Treatment : Dietary restriction of BCAAs (low protein diet). Special medical formulas without leucine, isoleucine, and valine. Thiamine supplementation: As BCKD is a thiamine-dependent enzyme. Reference: MSUD

questions.question: In a patient with Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), all of the following amino acids should be restricted in diet except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Methionine Explanation: Methionine breaks down in maple syrup urine disease. Maple syrup urine disease is a rare genetic disorder that affects the breakdown of the branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) leucine, isoleucine, and valine. In people with maple syrup urine disease, they cannot be metabolized properly due to a deficiency in the enzyme branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase. Burnt sugar odour from urine Ketosis Mental retardation Abnormal muscle tone Reference: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557773/

questions.question: Which of the following options best describes the mutation seen in patients with cystic fibrosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Phenylalanine at 508 position, chloride channel Explanation: The mutation seen in cystic fibrosis (CF) is CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene. Gene affected: CFTR gene, located on chromosome 7. Mutation type: The most common mutation is F508 (deletion of three nucleotides leading to the loss of phenylalanine at position 508). Effect : This mutation leads to defective CFTR protein, which functions as a chloride channel in epithelial cells. Pathophysiology : Defective chloride transport results in thick, sticky mucus affecting lungs, pancreas, and other organs. Inheritance : Autosomal recessive disorder. Clinical Features of Cystic Fibrosis (CF): Respiratory : Chronic cough, recurrent infections, bronchiectasis, nasal polyps. Gastrointestinal : Pancreatic insufficiency, malabsorption, meconium ileus, liver disease. Nutritional : Vitamin deficiencies (A, D, E, K), failure to thrive. Reference: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK493206/

questions.question: A 62-year-old male with CAD comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, height of 182 cm, weight of 85 kg, and a BMI of 25 kg/m². Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 95 mg/dL and homocysteine concentration of 19.3 µ mol/L (N=5–15). Serum lipid concentrations are within the normal range. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.explanation: high homocysteine levels is suggestive of homocystinuria caused by Cystathionine beta synthase deficiency is associated with homocystinuria. Homocystinuria: A genetic disorder characterized by elevated levels of homocysteine in the blood. The clinical manifestations of homocystinuria can include cardiovascular issues (such as early-onset atherosclerosis), skeletal abnormalities, intellectual disabilities, and other systemic complications. The patient in the question has an elevated homocysteine concentration, which is characteristic of homocystinuria. Types of Homocystinuria: Type 1 vs Type 2 Homocystinuria: Feature Type - I Homocystinuria Type - II Homocystinuria Enzyme Deficiency Cystathionine beta-synthase Methionine synthase Metabolic Pathway Affected Homocysteine to cystathionine Homocysteine to methionine Elevated Metabolites Homocysteine and methionine Homocysteine and elevated levels of methionine Biochemical Diagnosis Low levels of cysteine. High levels of methionine. High levels of cysteine. Low levels of methionine. Treatment Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation; low-methionine diet; cysteine supplementation Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation; low-methionine diet Homogentisate oxidase (Option A) deficiency leads to alkaptonuria, a condition characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid, causing darkening of urine and connective tissue. Cystathionine gamma synthase (Option C) deficiency is not a well-known enzyme deficiency associated with a specific clinical disorder. Cystathionine gamma synthase is involved in the transsulfuration pathway, converting cystathionine to cysteine. HGPRTase (Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase) (Option D) deficiency is seen in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is characterized by neurological and behavioral abnormalities, along with uric acid overproduction leading to gout.

questions.question: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is most likely?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Alkaptonuria Explanation: Alkaptonuria is Characterized by black urine upon standing due to the oxidation and polymerization of homogentisic acid (HGA). Alkaptonuria Definition Rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase (HGD) , an enzyme in the tyrosine metabolism pathway. Mechanism and Pathophysiology Defective tyrosine metabolism → homogentisic acid (HGA) accumulation → ochronotic pigment deposition → systemic disease (ochronosis). Deficiency: HGD fails to convert HGA to maleylacetoacetate. Consequences: HGA oxidizes into melanin-like polymers → connective tissue deposition (ochronosis). Affects joints, heart valves, kidneys, and vessels. Clinical Features Triad: Homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, ochronotic osteoarthropathy. Pediatric signs: Dark urine (oxidized HGA). Musculoskeletal : Arthritis (spine, hips, knees), kyphoscoliosis, spinal stenosis. Cardiac : A ortic stenosis, mitral valve disease, coronary artery disease. Renal/Metabolic: Stones (renal, gallbladder, prostate). Neurological : Peripheral neuropathy, stroke. Evaluation Clinical scoring: AKU Severity Score Index (AKUSSI). Diagnostic tests: Gold standard: Urinary HGA quantification via gas chromatography-mass spectrometry. Genetic testing for HGD mutations. Imaging (CT/MRI): Joint involvement, valvular calcification. Echocardiography: Valvular abnormalities. Management Symptomatic : Pain control, physiotherapy, joint surgery. Diet : Low-protein diet (limited efficacy). Medications: Vitamin C : Reduces HGA oxidation but not urinary excretion. Nitisinone : Inhibits tyrosine metabolism, reduces HGA >95%. Side effects: tyrosinemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia. Prognosis and Complications Prognosis : Normal life expectancy; reduced quality of life (pain, sleep issues, disability). Complications : Stones (renal, gallbladder, salivary). Tendon/ligament ruptures. Osteopenia, fractures. Aortic calcification/stenosis. Phenylketonuria (Option A): Caused by phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine. Symptoms include intellectual disability, seizures, and musty odor, but no black urine. Homocystinuria (Option C): Due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. Presents with lens dislocation, thromboembolism, and developmental delay, but not black urine. Maple Syrup Urine Disease (Option D): Results from branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase deficiency. Urine has a characteristic sweet odor but does not turn black on standing. Reference: Vasudevan Textbook of Biochemistry (7th Edition), Page 237, 238 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560571/ Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page 296, 304

questions.question: A chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. What biochemical changes will be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Increased urate and lactate levels Explanation: Increased Uric Acid (Hyperuricemia): Chronic alcohol consumption is a significant contributor to hyperuricemia, a condition characterized by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood. This occurs due to: Increased turnover of purines from alcohol metabolism. Decreased renal excretion of uric acid as lactate competes with uric acid for excretion through the kidneys. These factors increase the likelihood of uric acid crystal deposition in joints, triggering gouty arthritis. Increased Lactate Levels (Lactic Acidosis): Alcohol metabolism, particularly through the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, generates an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio. This shift favors the conversion of pyruvate to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis. Elevated lactate levels further impair the kidney's ability to excrete uric acid, exacerbating hyperuricemia and contributing to gout attacks. Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio (Option A): Alcohol metabolism increases the NADH/NAD+ ratio, which indirectly contributes to lactate production and hyperuricemia. Increased urea and urate levels (Option B): While urate levels increase, chronic alcohol use does not typically elevate urea levels unless there is concurrent kidney damage or protein metabolism disturbances. Increased level of alkaline phosphatase (Option D): This is associated with conditions like bone or liver disease but is not a key feature of gouty arthritis linked to alcohol consumption. Reference: Is lactic acid a misunderstood trigger of gout attack for a century? - ScienceDirect Gout Symptoms, Causes & Diet Recommendations | NIAMS
